transcript.title: Wisconsin Department of Health and Family Services v. Blumer

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Number oh oh nine five two, the Wisconsin Department of Health and Human Services versus Irene Blumer.
Ms. Flanagan.
[Inaudible]
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

In nineteen eighty-eight, Congress enacted the spousal impoverishment protections of the Federal Medicaid Act, forty two US Code section thirteen ninety-six R five, to accomplish two competing purposes.
First, Congress sought to protect spouses living at home from impoverishment when the other spouse is institutionalized and requires long-term nursing home care.
Secondly, Congress sought to ensure that married couples seeking Medicaid bear a fair share of the cost of such care.

This case concerns whether States have the discretion to achieve those competing goals by taking into account at the time Medicaid eligibility is determined available income which the nursing home spouse is permitted to use after eligibility to support the at-home spouse.

When the nursing home spouse applies for Medicaid, section thirteen ninety-six R five permits the community spouse to retain certain income and resources to mit- to meet his own monthly maintenance needs.

The statute permits an increase in the standard resource allowance, however, if the at-home spouse can show at a fair hearing that the allowance will be inadequate to provide him with income at the State-protected level once the nursing home spouse qualifies for Medicaid.

When making this determination, Wisconsin, like more than thirty other States, first considers whether income available to the at-home spouse from the nursing home spouse will be sufficient to ensure the protected level of income once Medicaid eligibility occurs.
This method of determining whether to increase or to substitute the standard resource allowance is called the income-first rule.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And what do the other States do?
The the remaining States use a methodology called resource first, in which they look first to the additional resources above the standard resource allowance.
The- These cases only arise where the couple has resources above the standard allowance.
In...
this case...

The the statutory provision, I think, specifically is found in forty-two US Code thirteen ninety-six A, sub A seven- sub seventeen, which deals with State standards for eligibility and and the Secretary's authority to set standards for...
determining availability.

Lawful, that's...
correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: are not permitted to do that?
That's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what...
i- i- with...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: a case like Batterton against Francis, then?
Well, Your Honor, I believe that in a case like Batterton B V Francis, w- we have a different set of rules here.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, but you know, it's still the general same ball park.
Mhm.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, you say the question is resolved.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And how how does that follow?

Well, there's a a couple of first of all, the the authority that the Secretary has relied on to issue its proposed rule and apparently from which its authority to develop the rule at all is thirteen ninety-six A A seventeen sub B.
one.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: This is very difficult to take...
in aurally.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But go ahead if you want.
It's almost as difficult to say it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I ask you a question? I know a case is easier if you don't look at the legislative history, and so it's probably easier for my colleague than it is for me.
Well, i- i- I've two responses to that, Justice Stevens.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In In that particular provision, to retain an adequate amount of resources, all that all that any other income attributable to the community spouse need mean is income attributable to him from sources other than interest on on on his on his resources.
The institutionalized spouse's wages, or the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The community spouse's...
Oh, yes,
absolutely.
I think it does.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I mean it...
Yes, I believe that it does...
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: is the resources that provide income, which means, you know, stocks or whatever, and all that phrase there need mean is something, any any other income attributable to him from something other than his stocks.
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Such as his wages,
right?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You your argument in in the event that we find ambiguity is I guess boils down simply to the fact that for a variety of reasons it would frustrate the congressional policy behind the act itself if we held against you, and yet in a in a way, haven't you provided a an answer to that, a counter to that argument in in your answer to a question a few moments ago? You you said, and I I think have to say, that if if the States lose on the particular issue before us here, the States as a practical matter can get to the same kind of rough dollar and cents result simply by adjusting the the the the the amount of resources, that is the the the the th- the baseline amount for the community spouse to retain and the amount of income which is thought to be necessary for the community spouse to to live decently, so it it it almost seems as though it doesn't very much matter, necessarily, to the enactment of whatever policy Congress had, whether the flexibility comes in income first versus resource first, or whether it comes in setting the the the allowances for income and assets.
Well, I think that the answer to that is that the resource-first allowance, refor- resource-first rule was placed in a provision that is what we call the fail safe provision.
but in...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: this is kind of an exceptional case kind of mechanism, regardless of how you set income and resources.
Absolutely.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And as an as a as an exceptional case mechanism, it's only going to work if it works the way you say, on a resource-first basis?
That's right, and and to stress the exceptional case component of it, you have to remember how you get one of these hearings.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Have you read the notice of the proposed rulemaking?
Yes, I have, Justice Ginsburg.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And I suppose your argument is to the effect that that is just not a permissible interpretation of the statute?
Yes, that's certainly one of our arguments against it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do we owe any deference to the agency here in its interpretation?
Well, because our position is that the position they're taking is totally unreasonable, no, you don't owe any deference to the agency.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does the income-first rule mean that at the end of the day less Federal money is spent on Medicaid care?
Not necessarily.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Would you comment on on c one of the questions I asked Mr. Lamken, whether the background rule is the name-on-the-check rule, or as he puts it, the ri- the better view is the background rule is one of deeming, and so that we should start from the premise that it's okay to treat one spouse's income as part of the other spouse.
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, even under this program, as I understand it, in the post eligibility determination the income can be transferred from the institutionalized spouse to the community spouse.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I might ask one question.
Tha- that was a question?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I was putting the thing...
because I I want you to...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: see that at the moment I'm thinking, well, I can't figure it out but I'm working with those examples and and since I can't, I say, leave it up to the Secretary, leave it up to the State, leave it up to somebody else as long as the statutue allows that I I wanted to expose that to you because I want you to have a chance to say, no, you're wrong, your example is wrong, your reasoning is wrong, everything's wrong, so, go ahead.
I I concur with everything you just said, Justice Breyer.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Although that you make a big point of that.
It would be.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I would have thought that your response would be the statutory language requires the result you're urging, but you don't make that argument, apparently.
No, no, we do make that...
argument, Justice O'Connor. Yes. The statutory language definitely does require...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: hear that in response to the question.
Well, it was in the opening that I didn't get a chance to make, so In your response to Justice Breyer, isn't it so, or am I counsel, am...
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: wrong in thinking that under ERISA there is a requirement to provide for the surviving spouse, it isn't the option of the insured individual?
Well, I'm no expert on ERISA, but I believe that there is a notice requirement and a sign-off requirement in ERISA.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But it's not the insured's election in the first place.
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: it isn't the wage earner's choice...
No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I don't want, usually her, to be any part of it.

That's right, but I think those decisions are made at a time when long-term care is not necessarily in the immediate offing, and maybe usually at age sixty-five or thereabouts, long before nursing home stays may be inevitable, and so the couple is making an informed choice about how best to maximize their income stream.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Hagopian, I want to come back to the snippet from legislative history that's referred to on page eighteen of the Government's brief.
I think I frankly agree with you, Justice Scalia.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Hagopian.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Know what I mean?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mm.
Thank you, Your Honor.
serve...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why is...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: that? I mean, he just...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: said on that that that and I certainly was in the briefs, that that if you say they have to spend down the three hundred thousand, they're not going to give it to the doctors in the institution.
Well, neither of us have any statistics on that.
also...
would have had money.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Ms. Flanagan.
